blocks.text: FIRST DAY: Saturday, July 11, 1959 – Lancaster, Pa., north through coal region of Pennsylvania, enter New York State, to Watkins Glen, to Taughannock Falls, along Cayuga Lake to Auburn, east to (near) Rome for first night. 8:30 A. M. to 8:45 P. M. 378 miles.
The initial problem...how to get all the baggage in the trunk of the car.
First stop at the Appalachian Trail (Louise has accidentally stepped on Cindy's foot; Cindy has socked her; first tiff). First tiiff.
Clearfield

blocks.text: In northern Penna., Wyalusing Rocks which overlook Susquehanna River.

A few miles beyond Wyalusing Rocks we come to a spot overlooking the valley where a group of French Royalists, fleeing from the Jacobin Revolution, in 1793 laid plans for an Asylum. A number of houses were built. It was hoped to bring Marie Antoinette here. Among those who settled were Louis Philippe, later king of France, and Talleyrand. Most of the settlers returned to France when Napoleon came to power.

blocks.text: One of many wayside restaurants which provide quick service on our trip.
The New York State Thruway which we follow around Syracuse to Utica, where we have trouble securing accommodations for night.

SECOND DAY: Sunday, July 12, - Rome N. Y., through Adirondacks, across Lake Champlain to Middlebury Vt., over Green Mountains via Lincoln Gap, to Ely, on Connecticut River. 6:55 A.M. to 6:00 P.M. 322 miles – total 700 miles.

The vast Adirondack State Park consists of 4,600,000 acres in northeastern New York. The western part is mostly lakes and wooded areas, while the eastern part is mountainous, with Mt. Marcy rising to 5,344'. Forty six other peaks reach 4,000'. The Park has become a huge vacation region. At the left is Mt. Whiteface and Lake Placid.

blocks.text: Across a narrow neck of Lake Champlain, leaving New York State for Vermont. Above, right is former location of Fort Crown Point, captured by Ethan Allen during the Revolution.

Middlebury College, Vermont,
founded in 1800 when region was wilderness area. (Cindy)
Over section of Green Mountains via Lincoln Gap...road extremely rough and steep...rain following us from the west.
Cottage near Ely, Vt., for night ($12) ... contains two bedrooms, kitchen and bath ... heavy rain soon after arrival.

blocks.text: THIRD DAY: Monday, July 13, 1959 - Ely, Vt., cross briefly into New Hampshire at Orford, due north in Vermont, enter Canada at Derby Line, continue north to Quebec City, east ten miles along St. Lawrence River. 8:05 A. M. to 6:00 P. M. 284 miles - total 984 miles.
Early morning, across the Connecticut River for brief visit in Orford, N. H. Here is post office where we send cards home.
One of seven stately old homes on the mall in Orford, said to be among the finest in New England.
Due north through Vermont where towns give way to almost unpopulated woods and mountains as we near Canada.
Lake Memphremagog is 30 mi. long and 4 mi. wide... seen at Newport, Vt. This lake bisects the border and extends far into Canada. We enter Canada at Derby Line....11:30 A.M.

blocks.text: Almost due north across Canada to Quebec. Rolling to flat farm land, well cultivated. Sun out, with white clouds after overcast sky of morning.

Nearly everything is French. Our girls have fun and difficulty trying to order meals.
Cold drink signs look familiar,
Exchange differential about 5% in favor of Canadian money, making travel in Canada this much more expensive.
Crossing St. Lawrence River from Levis to Quebec (a bargain, $1.20). Chateau Frontenac dominates skyline.

Planning to return to Quebec the next day, upon leaving the ferry we drive immediately along the north shore of the St. Lawrence for the Island of Orleans. Stop for night ( $10 ) at motel within sight of the long suspension bridge which connects the Island with the north shore.

blocks.text: FOURTH DAY: Tuesday, July 14, 1959 - Tour Ile D'Orleans, return to Quebec City, north through Laurende Park to Lake St. John, night near Chambord on Lake St. John. 8:10 A. M. to 4:30 P. M. 210 miles - total 1,194 miles.

The Island of Orleans is the very heart of French Canada. Time has stood still here. The picturesque farms and small villages are a page out of the past, in which the modern world has barely intruded. The 42 miles circle tour of the island requires only about two hours... "mist" for every tourist.

blocks.text: (Below) Monumentum memoriamt to Champlain, founder of Quebec, and one of New France's great explorers and statesmen.
Quebec City, where Cartier landed in 1535, selected by Champlain in 1608 as the capital of New France. Captured by English under General Wolfe at battle on Plains of Abraham in 1759.
Chateau Frontenac, one of world's great hostelsries.
Ancient dwellings, with one getting a very tight squeeze from its neighbors.
Cindy and Kitty return from a shopping trip unencumbered... "No bargains".

blocks.text: Due north from Quebec City we enter the Laurentides Park, four thousand square miles of untouched mountains, forests and lakes. We must secure a permit to enter, which we surrendered on leaving.
Village of St. Jerome....first view of Lake...

(Right) Sleeping accommodations are scarce, so we stop early (4:30 P. M.) at the first place we find, a surprisingly modern motel near Chambord ($12). The girls immediately go for their first swim in Lake St. John.

blocks.text: FIFTH DAY: Wednesday, July 15, 1959 - Circle Lake St. John to Saguenay River at Chicoutimi, east to St. Lawrence River at St. Simeon, across River by ferry to Riviere-du-Loup for night. 7:25 A. M. to 10:30 P. M. 275 miles - total 1,469 mi.

Proceeding around the Lake we come upon the village of St. Prime stretched out along the highway. Our French is not good: some-how for breakfast we get six orders of ham and eggs, toast, coffee (and yes) soup for our party of five ($4). Villagers drop in for a look at us, pretending to make some small purchase. Every one is friendly. We feel flattered by so much attention. Cindy tries out her school French on a girl about her own age...results almost negative.

blocks.text: One of several covered bridges.
Frequent wayside shrines attest the religious zeal of the French Canadians.
Across the Saguenay River at Chicoutimi, principal center of the region adjacent to some of the greatest power plants in Canada.
At this small restaurant on the east side of the Lake we are able for the first time to converse with a viillager in English.
At Bagotville on Baie des Ha! Ha!, a beautifully designed modern church.

blocks.text: which connects
Huge paper mill at Port Alfred.

After leaving Port Alfred we enter a mountainous wilderness area...very sparsely populated...fifty miles of rough road repairs (upper left) to plow through...dusty ...arrive at St. Simeon for ferry crossing of St. Lawrence River....we are second car unable to get on ferry...wait of three hours for next boat.

After leaving Port Alfred we enter a mountainous wilderness area...very sparsely populated...fifty miles of rough road repairs (upper left) to plow through...dusty ...arrive at St. Simeon for ferry crossing of St. Lawrence River....we are second car unable to get on ferry...wait of three hours for next boat.

blocks.text: While waiting for ferrry crossing we watch carefree French Canadian load logs on boat to be carried to some St. Lawrence River port.

Our Ferry (left) finally arrives, 8:30 P. M.
St. Lawrence so wide here we do not reach Riviere du Loup and motel ($15) until 10:30.
Every one tired.

SIXTH DAY: Thursday, July 16, 1959 - Riviere-du-Loup to Edmundston, re-enter U. S. at Madawaska, Maine, follow St. John River to Ft. Kent, south through Maine woods on R. 11 (view of Mt. Katahdin), east to East Musquash Lake for night. 10: A. M.
Across country from Riviere du Loup, headed for Edmundston and the U. S. line.

blocks.text: ONE LANE TRAFFIC
Covered bridge across Madawaska River in New Brunswick. Note unique sign.

Re-enter the U. S. at Madawaska, Maine - at customs only a few questions asked.
Re-entered on Thursday night and Friday morning in the U. S. S. S.
A river of logs to feed a paper mill.
Along the St. John River to Fort Kent. On the other side of the River is Canada.
(Upper right) The beginning of USHHighway #1 in Fort Kent. #1 runs south all the way to Key West, Florida.
( Lower right ) Blockhouse in Fort Kent was erected in 1841 as a defense during the "Aroostook War".

blocks.text: Log cabin for night at E. Musquash Lake.

South from Fort Kent through potato country of Maine. Road (R#11) turns rough, although hard-surfaced; sparsely populated forest region. Mt. Katahdin (5267'), highest point in Maine, barely visible in distance to west. A region of economic decline: fields go untended; young people leaving with work hard and winters long.
Eastport and Lubec, Maine, the two furthest east towns in the U. S., both in partial decline since failure of Quoddy project to harness high tides in area.

blocks.text: From West Quoddy Light, along the coast on a road so little used that grass grows in the center, to Cutler, where we find excellent restaurant on cove...celebrate with meal of steaks and lobster.
High suspension bridge across Penobscot River.
It's only about sixty miles to Damariscotta, but we are a day ahead of schedule, so we stop early at this rustic cottage near Belfast on Penobscot Bay.

( Below) As close as one could hope to find.
As once comee coundiddh hopppeee tcoo fndd.

Small lobster hutts such as this one abound in Maine, to their everlasting culinary glory. Fresh lobster, or crab meat, is served on a unique roll which resembles two pieces of bread, sawed in half, but joined at the bottom.

Replica of old Fort William Henry, orig. 1692.

Monument to Samoset, Indian chief who wel-come Pilgrims at Plymouth.

blocks.text: Louise and Cindy (left) accompany Gordon on visit to town of Friendship, where in years past Wilbur Morse built best boats ever made for lobster fishing, boats still prized to this day.
Boothbay Harbor, on peninsula south of our west, is one of best known harbors on Maine coast...delightful town, yachts of all description....locale of well known playhouse.

blocks.text: Brownville Junction.
Dover-Foxcroft
Old Town Bradley University of Maine

( Opposite page) Some of the stately old homes in Wiscasset, first settled in 17th century. Here Captain Samuel Clough hoped to bring Queen Marie Aintoineotte to safety from French Revolution. Town represents wealth from a world-wide shipping empire, which vanished with obsolescence of the wooden sailing ship. Rotting hulls. In Sheepscoot River at Wiscasset are familiar sight to tourists on Route #1.

blocks.text: FOURTEENTH DAY: Friday, July 24, 1959 - Leave Pemaquid Pond in afternoon, to Portland, west into New Hampshire to Laconia and Franklin, (to) Keene for night. 2:30 P. M. to 10:45 P. M. 236 miles – total 2,581 miles.
Final chance for a lobster roll at Brunswick, Maine. Note Gordon's reflection, with camera.
Into New Hampshire on a road little travelled by tourists.
The lake region of New Hampshire...this is Squam Lake.
After dark reach Concord, state capital...capitol dome modelled after Hotel des Invalides in Paris.

blocks.text: FIFTEENTH DAY: Saturday, July 25, 1959 - Keene to Brattleboro, across southern Vermont to Bennington, south through Massachusetts, into Connecticut at Canaan, into New York State, cross Hudson River at Poughkeepsie, skirt the Catskills to Ellenville, return to Pennsylvania at Port Jervis, and home via Stroudsburg, and Allentown. 8:30 A. M. to 10:50 P. M. 433 miles - total trip 3,014 miles.
Excellent example of New England covered bridge just west of Brattleboro, Vt.
Many roadside stands offer Vermont products for sale...baskets of all kinds, gloves, maple syrup, candy.

blocks.text: First night at this motel south of Yorktown ... a reasonable $9... 257 miles first day.

Monday morning we cross James River bridge. This is tidewater Virginia.
This is tidewater waterer Virgirgiiniiia..
The Intracoastal Waterway provides a sheltered route for small craft.

The Wright Brothers National Memorial...here was made the first successful power-driven airplane flight in history on 1903 at Kill Devil Hill in outer Banks. (About 390 miles from Lancaster.) Kitty and the girls are returning from a climb to the top of the memorial shaft, 60 feet high, of gray granite.

Gordon completely relaxed. We reserve our room for two nights, planning to drive to Ocracoke Island the next day.

blocks.text: Back on Hatteras, time out for a quick bite to eat.
On Weednessdaydoy, returnt to Bodie Island on the free ferry....much less trafficfficient.
The villages of Whalebone, Nags Head and Kitty Hawk offer many marine souvenirs for tourists. This is the area of extensive summer cottages and motels.
Fruit stand run by a Negress. We buy corn, tomatoes, beans, peaches and cantaloupes to take home with us..
On the way home, across Currituck Sound which separates the Outer Banks from the mainland.

blocks.text:
The Little Creek ferry across Chesapeake Bay,
89 miles from Nags Head. We wait only fifteen minutes to board.
Across Chesapeake Bay, eighteen nautical miles from Little Creek to Kiptopeke requiring one hour, forty minutes. (Fare $6.30, incl. car.)
MARYLAND STATE LINE

North on the peninsula south to the Maryland line at
2:00 P. M., , 155 miles from Nags Head...making excellent time.
Home at 6:30 P. M. after driving 327 miles from Nags Head. Total trip 994 miles.
End - trip to Outer Banks.
